title: Labour Ministry directs Karnataka to investigate delay in fresher onboarding at Infosys
description: The Ministry of Labour has directed the Karnataka State Labour Commissioner to address a complaint by IT union NITES regarding Infosys' delayed onboarding of over 2,000 candidates. Infosys has begun sending joining dates to impacted graduates, with plans to onboard all by December due to increased demand and revised revenue guidance.
content: Following a complaint by IT union, Nascent Information Technology Employees Senate (NITES) to the Ministry of Labour and Employment regarding the delayed onboarding of over 2,000 candidates by Infosys, the Labour Ministry has now directed the Karnataka State Labour Commissioner’s Office to take appropriate action under the relevant labour laws. The Ministry in a letter dated September 3rd, seen by ET, has urged the Karnataka Labour Department and said that since appropriate government for action under respective labour law in this matter is state government, "you are requested to look into this matter and take suitable action". IT union NITES last month had filed a formal complaint against Infosys to the Ministry of Labour over the delayed onboarding and “ongoing exploitation and unprofessional treatment” of over 2,000 young engineering graduates. These students were selected for system engineer (SE) and digital specialist engineer (DSE) roles during the 2022-23 recruitment drive.Meanwhile this week Infosys has already started sending joining dates to those impacted engineering graduates who have been awaiting onboarding for the last two years.The Bengaluru-based IT major had on Monday sent more than 1,000 appointment letters to freshers it had promised to hire in 2022. Even on Tuesday, a substantial number of letters were mailed by Infosys.
